Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment is violated when the landlord’s actions substantially impair the character and value of the tenancy.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion directly discusses the meaning of ‘quiet enjoyment’ under Massachusetts law, citing earlier cases and explaining that it protects tenants from serious interferences that impair the character and value of the premises. The court states that ‘quiet enjoyment’ signifies freedom from acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leased premises, thereby clearly recognizing that substantial impairment of the character and value of the tenancy constitutes a violation of the tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The common law background of § 14 also suggests that malicious intent is not a condition of liability. The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929) (quoting from Brande v. Grace, 154 Mass. 210, 212 [1891]).”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment is violated when the landlord’s actions substantially impair the character and value of the tenancy.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely recognizes that a landlord’s breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment occurs where the landlord’s conduct (including what he permits to be done) results in conditions that substantially deprive tenants of the beneficial use of their premises. The court affirms findings that the tenants were “very substantially deprived” of quiet enjoyment for a substantial time by noise from a lounge the landlord allowed and controlled, and holds this amounted to a constructive eviction and violation of the implied warranty of quiet enjoyment. This directly aligns with the proposition that substantial impairment of the character and value of the tenancy violates quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

Winograd v. Levine, 43 Mass. App. Ct. 30.raw_text: Winograd v. Levine, 43 Mass. App. Ct. 308 (1997)
Winograd v. Levine, 43 Mass. App. Ct. 30.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment is violated when the landlord’s actions substantially impair the character and value of the tenancy.
Winograd v. Levine, 43 Mass. App. Ct. 30.support_reasoning: This opinion is a partition/valuation case about fair market value of land with gravel deposits. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, quiet enjoyment, or any discussion of interference with a tenant’s use of leased premises. Because the court never addresses a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment or any similar doctrine, it cannot be cited as authority for that proposition under Massachusetts law.
Winograd v. Levine, 43 Mass. App. Ct. 30.relevant_excerpt: There is no discussion in the opinion of quiet enjoyment, landlord-tenant relationships, or interference with tenancy; the case exclusively concerns methods of valuing co-owned real property for partition, particularly land containing gravel deposits.

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment is violated when the landlord’s actions substantially impair the character and value of the tenancy.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly holds that a landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season “seriously impairs the character and value of the leased premises” and that this constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law. The court thus directly links substantial impairment of the character and value of the tenancy to a violation of the tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, squarely supporting the proposition stated.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season… seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ (Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 [1929], quoting from Brande v. Grace, 154 Mass. 210, 212 [1891]), and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment… Thus… liability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment is violated when the landlord’s actions substantially impair the character and value of the tenancy.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The court reiterates the established standard for liability under the Massachusetts quiet enjoyment statute, explaining that liability arises where a landlord’s negligent failure to address known problems leads to interference with the tenant’s rights and that § 14 imposes liability whenever the natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s action is interruption of the tenant’s rights. This reflects the principle that quiet enjoyment is violated when the landlord’s conduct substantially impairs the character and value of the tenancy, even though the specific issue here is whether a lead paint statutory violation alone suffices.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: We have also said that § 14 imposes liability whenever the “ ‘natural and probable consequence’ of a landlord’s action was interruption of the tenant’s rights.” Simon v. Solomon, supra at 102, quoting Westland Hous. Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mass. 375, 381 (1942). In Cruz, we observed that the landlord had notice of the defects in the leased premises which it failed to repair, and that it was “wholly foreseeable” that the injury to the tenant would result from this failure to make the repairs. Indeed, in each case since the 1973 statutory revision in which we have recognized a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, there was evidence that the landlord failed to act reasonably in the circumstances concerning a problem known to the landlord, and the natural and probable consequences of such failure caused the interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.

Dolben Co. v. Friedmann, 1 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Dolben Co. v. Friedmann, 1 Mass. App. Ct. 701 (1974)
Dolben Co. v. Friedmann, 1 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment is violated when the landlord’s actions substantially impair the character and value of the tenancy.
Dolben Co. v. Friedmann, 1 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal case about armed robbery, speedy trial, jury selection, evidentiary rulings, and related criminal procedure issues. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, quiet enjoyment, or any discussion of interference with the character or value of a tenancy. Therefore it cannot be authority for the stated proposition regarding a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment in Massachusetts.
Dolben Co. v. Friedmann, 1 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: [No relevant excerpt. The case concerns criminal convictions for armed robbery and associated procedural issues, and does not mention landlord-tenant law or quiet enjoyment.}

Morrison v. Lennett, 415 Mass. 857 (1993.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment is violated when the landlord’s actions substantially impair the character and value of the tenancy.
Morrison v. Lennett, 415 Mass. 857 (1993.support_reasoning: The opinion in Morrison v. Lennett deals exclusively with the charitable immunity damages cap under G.L. c. 231, § 85K, the nature of nominee trusts, and the personal versus representative liability of trustees and officers. It does not discuss landlord-tenant law, quiet enjoyment, or standards for when a landlord’s actions substantially impair the character and value of a tenancy. Therefore it provides no authority for the stated proposition about a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law.
Morrison v. Lennett, 415 Mass. 857 (1993.relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 231, § 85K (1990 ed.), provides, in pertinent part, as follows: “It shall not constitute a defense to any cause of action based on tort brought against a corporation, trustees of a trust, or members of an association that said corporation, trust, or, association is or at the time the cause of action arose was a charity; provided, that if the tort was committed in the course of any activity carried on to accomplish directly the charitable purposes of such corporation, trust, or association, liability in any such cause of action shall not exceed the sum of twenty thousand dollars exclusive of interest and costs.”

G.L. c. 186, \u00a714.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, §14, a landlord who “directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant” is liable for damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a719C.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §19C and G.L. c. 186, §14, as this is a landlord-tenant matter involving a residential lease within the Cambridge District Court’s territorial jurisdiction.

G.L. c. 239, \u00a72A.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment is violated when the landlord’s actions substantially impair the character and value of the tenancy.

G.L. c. 93A, \u00a79.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment is violated when the landlord’s actions substantially impair the character and value of the tenancy.
